verses.text: The Pharisees and some of the scribes who had come from Jerusalem gathered around Jesus.
verses.comment: The presence of religious leaders from Jerusalem shows Jesus' growing fame and the growing opposition to Him from religious authorities.

verses.text: And they saw that some of His disciples were eating their bread with hands that were unwashed, meaning ceremonially unclean.
verses.comment: The issue is not physical cleanliness but ritual purity, a key concept in the Jewish law.

verses.text: For the Pharisees and all the Jews do not eat unless they wash their hands carefully, holding to the tradition of the elders.
verses.comment: The 'tradition of the elders' refers to oral traditions that had been accumulated beyond the written Law.

verses.text: And when they come from the marketplace, they do not eat unless they wash. And there are many other traditions they keep—washings of cups, pitchers, and kettles.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the elaborate ritual purity laws practiced by the Pharisees. These traditions were considered authoritative yet were not found explicitly in the Mosaic Law.

verses.text: So the Pharisees and scribes asked Him, 'Why do Your disciples not walk according to the tradition of the elders, but eat with unwashed hands?'
verses.comment: The challenge is against Jesus’ authority to allow His followers to bypass traditions.

verses.text: But He said to them, 'Well did Isaiah prophesy about you hypocrites, as it is written: “This people honors Me with their lips, but their heart is far from Me.”'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Isaiah, equating the Pharisees with those who honor God only externally, not from the heart. This warning against mere ritualism stands throughout Christian tradition.

verses.text: 'And in vain do they worship Me, teaching as doctrines the commandments of men.'
verses.comment: Jesus makes a distinction between human traditions and the commandments of God, highlighting the danger of elevating human customs.

verses.text: You leave the commandment of God and hold fast to the tradition of men.
verses.comment: This rebuke underscores the primacy of God's commandments over human traditions.

verses.text: And He said to them, 'You have a fine way of rejecting the commandment of God in order to establish your tradition!'
verses.comment: A strong criticism of substituting God’s law with human rules.

verses.text: For Moses said, “Honor your father and your mother,” and, “Whoever speaks evil of father or mother must surely die.”
verses.comment: Jesus cites the foundational Ten Commandments, highlighting their non-negotiable authority.

verses.text: But you say, ‘If a man tells his father or mother, “Whatever benefit you might have received from me is Corban” (that is, a gift devoted to God),’
verses.comment: Corban was a practice of dedicating resources to God, making them unavailable for parental support—a twist of devotion that contradicted the Law’s spirit.

verses.text: then you no longer let him do anything for his father or mother.
verses.comment: The tradition of declared ‘Corban’ nullified genuine charity and responsibility, which Christ raises as a serious error.

verses.text: Thus you nullify the word of God by your tradition that you have handed down. And you do many things like this.
verses.comment: Jesus' critique still echoes today: human traditions can never take precedence over God’s revelation.

verses.text: Then He called the crowd to Him again and said to them, 'Listen to Me, all of you, and understand.'
verses.comment: Jesus here openly teaches the people, making His message accessible to all, highlighting His role as the authoritative teacher.

verses.text: 'There is nothing outside a person that by going into him can make him unclean. But the things that come out of a person are what make him unclean.'
verses.comment: A revolutionary teaching that shifts the emphasis from external rituals to the internal state of the heart.

verses.text: If anyone has ears to hear, let him hear.
verses.comment: A call for spiritual attentiveness, a phrase Jesus often uses, stressing the importance of rightly understanding His words.

verses.text: And when He had entered the house and left the crowd, His disciples asked Him about the parable.
verses.comment: Shows Jesus’ close relationship with His disciples and their privileged access to His deeper explanations (see Mark 4:34).

verses.text: And He said to them, 'Are you also without understanding? Do you not see that whatever goes into a person from outside cannot make him unclean?
verses.comment: Jesus patiently clarifies the spiritual nature of purity. The concern is with the soul, not bodily ceremonies.

verses.text: Because it does not enter his heart but his stomach, and then is expelled?' By this He declared all foods clean.
verses.comment: Here, Jesus sets aside the old ceremonial dietary laws, a significant move later affirmed in Acts. This shows His authority to adjust ritual regulations, pointing to His divinity.

verses.text: And He said, 'What comes out of a person is what makes him unclean.'
verses.comment: The real defilement is moral and spiritual, not physical.

verses.text: 'For from within, out of the heart of man, come evil thoughts, sexual immorality, theft, murder, adultery,'
verses.comment: Jesus lists sins proceeding from the heart, echoing the teaching on original sin and the need for inner renewal.

verses.text: 'coveting, wickedness, deceit, sensuality, envy, slander, pride, and foolishness.'
verses.comment: The catalogue of sins emphasizes the universality of human sinfulness.

verses.text: 'All these evil things come from within and make a person unclean.'
verses.comment: A spiritual diagnosis of the source of sin, shaping later Christian moral teaching.

verses.text: And Jesus arose and went away from there to the region of Tyre and Sidon. He entered a house and did not want anyone to know, but He could not escape notice.
verses.comment: Jesus enters Gentile territory, hinting at the universal scope of His mission.

verses.text: But immediately a woman whose little daughter had an unclean spirit heard about Him and came and fell at His feet.
verses.comment: Her action is a sign of humble faith and supplication. Jesus responds to persistent and humble seekers.

verses.text: Now the woman was a Greek, a Syrophoenician by birth. And she begged Him to cast the demon out of her daughter.
verses.comment: The woman’s Gentile identity highlights Jesus’ openness to all who truly seek Him, previewing the inclusion of the nations.

verses.text: But He said to her, 'Let the children be fed first, for it is not right to take the children’s bread and throw it to the dogs.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ words reflect the Jewish priority in salvation history, but not its exclusivity. The blessing for Gentiles follows, not replaces, Israel.

verses.text: But she replied, 'Yes, Lord; yet even the dogs under the table eat the children’s crumbs.'
verses.comment: Her humility and faith confess Jesus as Lord; her answer is an example of persevering prayer and trust.

verses.text: And He said to her, 'For this statement you may go your way; the demon has left your daughter.'
verses.comment: Jesus honors humility and persistent faith—this also foreshadows the blessings that will come to the Gentiles through Him.

verses.text: She went home and found the child lying in bed and the demon gone.
verses.comment: A miracle accomplished at a distance, showing Jesus’ authority over the spiritual realm—another sign of His divine power.

verses.text: Then He returned from the region of Tyre, and went through Sidon to the Sea of Galilee, in the region of the Decapolis.
verses.comment: Jesus travels through a Gentile-dominated region, showing His mission's expanding outreach.

verses.text: And they brought to Him a man who was deaf and had a speech impediment, and they begged Him to lay His hand on him.
verses.comment: Physical healing fulfills Old Testament prophecy that the Messiah would give hearing to the deaf and speech to the mute.

verses.text: And taking him aside from the crowd privately, He put His fingers into his ears, and after spitting, He touched his tongue.
verses.comment: Jesus uses physical signs as visible expressions of His healing power, much like visible signs connected to spiritual realities in Christian sacramental practice.

verses.text: And looking up to heaven, He sighed and said to him, 'Ephphatha,' that is, 'Be opened.'
verses.comment: 'Ephphatha' is Aramaic. Jesus prays and commands, indicating both divine power and dependence on the Father, expressing the unity between Jesus and God.

verses.text: And his ears were opened, his tongue was released, and he spoke plainly.
verses.comment: A complete instant healing, further establishing Jesus’ Messianic identity (see Isa. 35:5).

verses.text: And Jesus ordered them to tell no one. But the more He ordered them, the more they spread the news.
verses.comment: The Messianic secret: Jesus often instructs people to be silent about His miracles until the time of His full revelation.

verses.text: And they were astonished beyond measure, saying, 'He has done all things well. He even makes the deaf hear and the mute speak.'
verses.comment: The crowd’s reaction echoes Isaiah’s prophecy about the coming Messiah, affirming that Jesus fulfills these ancient promises, revealing His divine mission and caring authority for all people.
